original: Majjhima Nikāya 14
analyzed: majjhima nikāya
translated: Middle Length Discourses

original: Cūḷadukkhakkhandhasutta
analyzed: cūḷa dukkha kkhandha sutta
translated: The Shorter Section on the Mass of Suffering

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṁ nigrodhārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmin nigrodha ārāme
translated: At one time the Buddha was staying in the Sakyan country, at Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

original: Atha kho mahānāmo sakko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho mahānāmo sakko bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:🔽“dīgharattāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavatā evaṁ dhammaṁ desitaṁ ājānāmi:
analyzed: atha khalu mahānāmaḥ sakkaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ khalu mahānāmaḥ sakkaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca  dīgharattā āha bhante bhagavatā evam dhammam desitam ājānāmi
translated: Then Mahanama the Sakyan went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down, and said, “Venerable Sir, for a long time I’ve understood the Teaching like this:

original: ‘lobho cittassa upakkileso, doso cittassa upakkileso, moho cittassa upakkileso’ti.
analyzed: lobho cittassa upakkilesaḥ doso cittassa upakkilesaḥ moho cittassa upakkilesaḥ ti
translated: ‘Greed, hate, and delusion are mental defilements.’

original: Evañcāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavatā dhammaṁ desitaṁ ājānāmi:
analyzed: evam ca āha bhante bhagavatā dhammam desitam ājānāmi
translated: And I understand the Teaching like this:

original: ‘lobho cittassa upakkileso, doso cittassa upakkileso, moho cittassa upakkileso’ti.
analyzed: lobho cittassa upakkilesaḥ doso cittassa upakkilesaḥ moho cittassa upakkilesaḥ ti
translated: ‘Greed, hate, and delusion are mental defilements.’

original: Atha ca pana me ekadā lobhadhammāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti, dosadhammāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti, mohadhammāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: atha ca pana me ekadā lobha dhammā api cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti dosa dhammā api cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti moha dhammā api cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti
translated: But sometimes my mind is still overwhelmed by thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and violence.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, evaṁ hoti:🔽‘kosu nāma me dhammo ajjhattaṁ appahīno yena me ekadā lobhadhammāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya
analyzed: tassa bhante evam hoti  nāma me dhammaḥ ajjhattam appahīnaḥ yena me ekadā lobha dhammā api cittam pariyādāya
translated: I think:

original: tiṭṭhanti, dosadhammāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti, mohadhammāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhantī’”ti.🔽“So eva kho te, mahānāma, dhammo ajjhattaṁ appahīno yena te ekadā lobhadhammāpi cittaṁ
analyzed: tiṭṭhanti dosa dhammā api cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti moha dhammā api cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti iti  saḥ eva kho te mahā nāma dhammaḥ ajjhattam appahīnaḥ yena te ekadā lobha dhammā api citta
translated: ‘What is that underlying tendency in me that sometimes leads to my mind being overwhelmed by thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and violence?’”

original: pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti, dosadhammāpi cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti, mohadhammāpi cittaṁ🔽pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti dosa dhammā api cittam pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti moha dhammā api citta  pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti
translated: “That underlying tendency in you that has not yet been abandoned is what sometimes leads to your mind being overwhelmed by thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and violence.

original: So ca hi te, mahānāma, dhammo ajjhattaṁ pahīno abhavissa, na tvaṁ agāraṁ ajjhāvaseyyāsi, na kāme paribhuñjeyyāsi.
analyzed: saḥ ca hi te mahānāma dhammaḥ ajjhattam pahīnaḥ abhavissa na tvam agāram ajjhāvaseyyāsi na kāme paribhuñjeyyāsi
translated: If that underlying tendency had already been abandoned, you would not live the home life enjoying sensual pleasures.

original: Yasmā ca kho te, mahānāma, so eva dhammo ajjhattaṁ appahīno tasmā tvaṁ agāraṁ ajjhāvasasi, kāme paribhuñjasi.
analyzed: yasmai ca kho te mahānāma saḥ eva dhammaḥ ajjhattam appahīno tasmai tvam agāram ajjhāvasasi kāme paribhuñjasi
translated: But since you have not given up that view, you live in a house, enjoy sensual pleasures, and are not a monastic who has gone forth into homelessness.

original: ‘Appassādā kāmā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti—
analyzed: appassādā kāmā bahu dukkhā bahu pāyāsā ādīnavaḥ ettha bhiyyaḥ ti
translated: ‘Sensual pleasures give little satisfaction and cause much suffering and much despair, and the danger in them is greater.’

original: iti cepi, mahānāma, ariyasāvakassa yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṁ hoti, so ca aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi pītisukhaṁ nādhigacchati, aññaṁ vā tato santataraṁ;
analyzed: iti ce pi mahānāma ariya sāvakassa yathābhūtam sammappaññāya su diṭṭham hoti saḥ ca aññatra iva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi pīti sukham na adhigacchati aññam vā tatas santatara
translated: “If a noble disciple has seen this peril in sensual pleasures as it actually is with proper wisdom, and if he has made a connection with the good Dhamma, and if he has a virtuous behavior that inspires confidence, is untarnished, impeccable, admirable, and well-practiced, and if he has made a connection with the good Dhamma, and if he has the wisdom that penetrates the Dhamma, then he is called a noble disciple who is a stream-enterer, no longer bound to the nether world, fixed in destiny, with enlightenment as his destination.”

original: atha kho so neva tāva anāvaṭṭī kāmesu hoti.🔽Yato ca kho, mahānāma, ariyasāvakassa ‘appassādā kāmā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo🔽ettha bhiyyo’ti—evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṁ hoti, so ca aññatreva
analyzed: atha kho saḥ na iva tāva an āvaṭṭī kāmesu hoti  yatas ca kho mahānāma ariya sāvakassa appassādā kāmāḥ bahu dukkhāḥ bahu pāyāsā ādīnavaḥ  ettha bhiyyo ti evam etam yathābhūtam sammappaññāya su diṭṭham hoti saḥ ca aññatra eva
translated: But since you have not given up that view, you live in a house, enjoy sensual pleasures, and are not a monastic who has gone forth into homelessness.

original: kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi pītisukhaṁ adhigacchati aññaṁ vā tato santataraṁ;🔽atha kho so anāvaṭṭī kāmesu hoti.
analyzed: kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi pīti sukham adhigacchati aññam vā tatas santatara 🔽atha kho saḥ an āvaṭṭī kāmesu hoti
translated: But when a noble disciple has seen this peril in sensual pleasures as it actually is with proper wisdom, and has made a connection with the good Dhamma, and has a virtuous behavior that inspires confidence, is untarnished, impeccable, admirable, and well-practiced, and has made a connection with the good Dhamma, and has the wisdom that penetrates the Dhamma, then he is called a noble disciple who is a stream-enterer, no longer bound to the nether world, fixed in destiny, with enlightenment as his destination.”

original: Mayhampi kho, mahānāma, pubbeva sambodhā, anabhisambuddhassa bodhisattasseva sato,
analyzed: mayham pi kho mahā nāma pubbā iva sambodhā an abhisambuddhassa bodhisattassa iva sataḥ
translated: Before my awakening, while I was still a bodhisatta, not yet fully awakened,

original: ‘appassādā kāmā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti—evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṁ hoti,
analyzed: appassādāḥ kāmāḥ bahu dukkhāḥ bahu pāyāsāḥ ādīnavaḥ ettha bhiyyaḥ ti evam etat yathābhūtam sammappaññāya su diṭṭham hoti
translated: I too saw as it actually is with proper wisdom: ‘Sensual pleasures provide little gratification, much suffering and much despair. The danger in them is greater.’

original: so ca aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi pītisukhaṁ nājjhagamaṁ, aññaṁ vā tato santataraṁ;
analyzed: so ca aññatra iva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi pīti sukham na ajjhagama aññam vā tatas santatara
translated: But I did not attain a pleasant abiding that is apart from sensual pleasures, apart from unskillful qualities, or something more peaceful than that.

original: atha khvāhaṁ neva tāva anāvaṭṭī kāmesu paccaññāsiṁ.🔽Yato ca kho me, mahānāma, ‘appassādā kāmā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo’ti—evametaṁ
analyzed: atha khvā aham na iva tāva an āvaṭṭī kāmesu paccaññā asi  yatas ca kho me mahānāma appassādāḥ kāmāḥ bahu dukkhāḥ bahu pāyāsāḥ ādīnavaḥ ettha
translated: So I did not turn away from sensual pleasures right then and there.🔽But when I saw as it actually is with proper wisdom that ‘Sensual pleasures provide little gratification, much suffering and much despair. The danger in them is greater,’

original: yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya sudiṭṭhaṁ ahosi, so ca aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi
analyzed: yathābhūtam sammappaññāya su diṭṭham ahosi saḥ ca aññatra iva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi
translated: I attained a pleasant abiding that is apart from sensual pleasures, apart from unskillful qualities,

original: dhammehi pītisukhaṁ ajjhagamaṁ, aññaṁ vā tato santataraṁ;
analyzed: dhammehi pīti sukham ajjhagama aññam vā tatas santatara
translated: or something more peaceful than that.

original: athāhaṁ anāvaṭṭī kāmesu paccaññāsiṁ.
analyzed: atha aham an āvaṭṭī kāmesu paccaññā asi
translated: So I turned away from sensual pleasures right then and there.

original: Ko ca, mahānāma, kāmānaṁ assādo?
analyzed: kaḥ ca mahānāma kāmānam assādaḥ
translated: “And what, Mahanama, is the gratification of sensual pleasures?

original: Pañcime, mahānāma, kāmaguṇā.
analyzed: pañcime mahānāma kāmaguṇā
translated: There are these five cords of sensual pleasure.

original: Katame pañca?
analyzed: katame pañca
translated: What are the five?

original: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā;🔽sotaviññeyyā saddā …pe…🔽ghānaviññeyyā gandhā …
analyzed: cakkhu viññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piya rūpā kāma upasahitā rajanīyā  sota viññeyyā saddāḥ pe  ghāna viññeyyāḥ gandhāḥ
translated: Forms cognizable by the eye that are wished for, desired, agreeable, and likeable, connected with sensual desire and provocative of lust.🔽Sounds cognizable by the ear…🔽Odours cognizable by the nose…

original: jivhāviññeyyā rasā …
analyzed: jivhā viññeyyāḥ rasāḥ
translated: Flavours cognizable by the tongue…

original: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā—
analyzed: kāya viññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piya rūpā kāma upasahitā rajanīyā
translated: Tangibles cognizable by the body that are wished for, desired, agreeable, and likeable, connected with sensual desire and provocative of lust.

original: ime kho, mahānāma, pañca kāmaguṇā.
analyzed: ime khalu mahānāma pañca kāmaguṇā
translated: These are the five cords of sensual pleasure.

original: Yaṁ kho, mahānāma, ime pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṁ somanassaṁ—
analyzed: yam kho mahānāma ime pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukham somanassa
translated: The pleasure and joy that arise in dependence on these five cords of sensual pleasure:

original: ayaṁ kāmānaṁ assādo.
analyzed: ayam kāmānam assādaḥ
translated: this is the gratification in sensual pleasures.

original: Ko ca, mahānāma, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo?
analyzed: kaḥ ca mahānāma kāmānam ādīnavaḥ
translated: “And what, Mahanama, is the danger in sensual pleasures?

original: Idha, mahānāma, kulaputto yena sippaṭṭhānena jīvikaṁ kappeti—
analyzed: idha mahā nāma kula putto yena sippa ṭṭhānena jīvikam kappeti
translated: Here, Mahanama, a clansman earns his living by some craft or occupation.

original: yadi muddāya yadi gaṇanāya yadi saṅkhānena yadi kasiyā yadi vaṇijjāya yadi gorakkhena yadi issatthena yadi rājaporisena yadi sippaññatarena,
analyzed: yadi muddāya yadi gaṇanāya yadi saṅkhānena yadi kasiyā yadi vaṇijjāya yadi gorakkhena yadi issatthena yadi rāja porisena yadi sippaññatarena
translated: Whether by farming or trade, by lending money, by raising cattle, by learning, or by taking service under a king.

original: sītassa purakkhato uṇhassa purakkhato ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassehi rissamāno khuppipāsāya mīyamāno;
analyzed: sītassa purakkhataḥ uṇhassa purakkhataḥ ḍasama kasa vāta ātapa sarīsapa samphassehi rissamānaḥ khuppipāsāya mīyamānaḥ
translated: He is afflicted by cold, heat, and contact with flies, mosquitoes, wind, the sun, and serpents. He is afflicted by hunger and thirst. He experiences painful, racking, piercing feelings.

original: ayampi, mahānāma, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
analyzed: ayam pi mahānāma kāmānam ādīnavaḥ sandiṭṭhikaḥ dukkha kkhandhaḥ kāma hetu kāma nidānam kāma adhikaraṇam kāmānam eva hetu
translated: This is the danger in sensual pleasures that is visible in this very life.

original: Tassa ce, mahānāma, kulaputtassa evaṁ uṭṭhahato ghaṭato vāyamato te bhogā nābhinipphajjanti,
analyzed: tassa ce mahānāma kula puttassa evam uṭṭhahataḥ ghaṭataḥ vā āyamataḥ te bhogāḥ na abhinipphajjanti
translated: “If, Mahānāma, that clansman who strives and exerts himself in this way does not attain the destruction of the taints,

original: so socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṁ kandati sammohaṁ āpajjati ‘moghaṁ vata me uṭṭhānaṁ, aphalo vata me vāyāmo’ti.🔽Ayampi, mahānāma, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
analyzed: saḥ socati kilamati paridevati urat tāḷim kandati sammoham āpajjati mogham vata me uṭṭhāna aphalaḥ vata me vāyāmaḥ iti  ayam pi mahānāma kāmānam ādīnavaḥ sandiṭṭhikaḥ dukkha kkhandhaḥ kāma hetu kāma nidānam kāma adhikaraṇam kāmānam eva hetu
translated: he grieves, languishes, and laments; he weeps beating his breast and becomes confused. He thinks: ‘My striving has been in vain, my exertion has been fruitless.’🔽This is the danger in sensual pleasures that is visible in this very life.

original: Tassa ce, mahānāma, kulaputtassa evaṁ uṭṭhahato ghaṭato vāyamato te bhogā abhinipphajjanti.
analyzed: tassa ce mahānāma kula puttassa evam uṭṭhahataḥ ghaṭataḥ vā āyamataḥ te bhogāḥ abhinipphajjanti
translated: “If, Mahānāma, that clansman who strives and exerts himself in this way attains the destruction of the taints,

original: So tesaṁ bhogānaṁ ārakkhādhikaraṇaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti:
analyzed: so tesam bhogānam ārakkha adhikaraṇam dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti
translated: He experiences pain and sorrow in guarding and protecting his wealth.

original: ‘kinti me bhoge neva rājāno hareyyuṁ, na corā hareyyuṁ, na aggi daheyya, na udakaṁ vaheyya, na appiyā vā dāyādā hareyyun’ti.
analyzed: kinti me bhoge na iva rājānaḥ hareyyu na corāḥ hareyyu na aggi daheyya na udakam vaheyya na appiyāḥ vā dāyādāḥ hareyyunti
translated: ‘How can neither kings nor thieves make off with my wealth, nor fire burn it, nor water carry it away, nor unloved heirs make off with it?’

original: Tassa evaṁ ārakkhato gopayato te bhoge rājāno vā haranti, corā vā haranti, aggi vā dahati, udakaṁ vā vahati, appiyā vā dāyādā haranti.
analyzed: tassa evam ārakkhataḥ gopayataḥ te bhoge rājānaḥ vā haranti corāḥ vā haranti aggi vā dahati udakam vā vahati appiyāḥ vā dāyādāḥ haranti
translated: But even though he guards and protects his wealth in this way, kings may still make off with it, or thieves may make off with it, or fire may burn it, or water may carry it away, or unloved heirs may make off with it.

original: So socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṁ kandati sammohaṁ āpajjati:
analyzed: saḥ socati kilamati paridevati uras tāḷim kandati sammoham āpajjati
translated: He sorrows, grieves and laments, beats his breast, weeps and becomes distraught,

original: ‘yampi me ahosi tampi no natthī’ti.🔽Ayampi, mahānāma, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
analyzed: yam pi me ahosi tam pi no natthi iti  ayam pi mahānāma kāmānam ādīnavaḥ sandiṭṭhikaḥ dukkha kkhandhaḥ kāma hetu kāma nidānam kāma adhikaraṇam kāmānam eva hetu
translated: saying: ‘What was mine is no more!’🔽This is the danger in sensual pleasures, the future peril belonging to sensual pleasures, which is worse still.

original: Puna caparaṁ, mahānāma, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu rājānopi
analyzed: punar capara mahā nāma kāma hetu kāma nidānam kāma adhikaraṇam kāmānam eva
translated: Again, Mahanama, because of sensual pleasures, because of sensual desires, kings quarrel with kings, nobles with nobles, brahmins with brahmins, householders with householders, mother with child, child with mother, father with child, child with father, brother with brother, sister with sister, brother with sister, sister with brother, friend with friend.

original: rājūhi vivadanti, khattiyāpi khattiyehi vivadanti, brāhmaṇāpi brāhmaṇehi vivadanti,🔽gahapatīpi gahapatīhi vivadanti, mātāpi puttena vivadati, puttopi mātarā vivadati,🔽pitāpi puttena vivadati, puttopi pitarā vivadati, bhātāpi bhātarā vivadati, bhātāpi
analyzed: rājūhi vivadanti khattiyā api khattiyehi vivadanti brāhmaṇā api brāhmaṇehi vivadanti  gahapatī ipi gahapatīhi vivadanti mātā api puttena vivadati puttaḥ api mātarā vivadati  pitā api puttena vivadati puttaḥ api pitarā vivadati bhātā api bhātarā vivadati bhātā api
translated: They dispute with kings, nobles, and brahmins,🔽householders, and even with their own parents.🔽They dispute with their brothers, sisters,

original: bhaginiyā vivadati, bhaginīpi bhātarā vivadati, sahāyopi sahāyena vivadati.
analyzed: bhaginiyā vivadati bhaginī ipi bhātarā vivadati sahāyaḥ upi sahāyena vivadati
translated: friends, and companions.🔽In their disputes they strike each other with their hands,

original: Te tattha kalahaviggahavivādāpannā aññamaññaṁ pāṇīhipi upakkamanti, leḍḍūhipi upakkamanti, daṇḍehipi upakkamanti, satthehipi upakkamanti.
analyzed: te tattha kalaha viggaha vivāda āpannāḥ aññamaññam pāṇīhi pi upakkamanti leḍḍūhi pi upakkamanti daṇḍehi pi upakkamanti satthehi pi upakkamanti
translated: clods, sticks, and swords.

original: Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti, maraṇamattampi dukkhaṁ.
analyzed: te tattha maraṇam pi nigacchanti maraṇa mattam pi dukkha
translated: Because of this they undergo death and deadly suffering.

original: Ayampi, mahānāma, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
analyzed: ayam pi mahānāma kāmānam ādīnavaḥ sandiṭṭhikaḥ dukkha kkhandhaḥ kāma hetu kāma nidānam kāma adhikaraṇam kāmānam eva hetu
translated: This is the danger in sensual pleasures, the mass of suffering and distress that has sensual pleasures as its source,🔽its origin, its birth, its source, its production, its origination, its arising.

original: Puna caparaṁ, mahānāma, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu asicammaṁ
analyzed: punar capara mahā nāma kāma hetu kāma nidānam kāma adhikaraṇam kāmānam eva hetu asi camma
translated: “Again, Mahanama, it is with sensuality for the reason, sensuality for the source… that they take up swords and shields,🔽arm themselves with bows and arrows, and engage in battle with clubs.🔽There, swords and arrows and spears

original: gahetvā, dhanukalāpaṁ sannayhitvā, ubhatobyūḷhaṁ saṅgāmaṁ pakkhandanti usūsupi khippamānesu,🔽sattīsupi khippamānāsu, asīsupi vijjotalantesu.🔽Te tattha usūhipi vijjhanti, sattiyāpi vijjhanti, asināpi sīsaṁ chindanti.
analyzed: gahetvā dhanu kalāpam sannayhitvā ubhatobyūḷham saṅgāmam pakkhandanti usūsupi khippamānesu  sattīsupi khippamānāsu asīsupi  te tattha usūhi api vijjhanti sattiyā api vijjhanti asinā api sīsam chindanti
translated: are smeared with blood,

original: Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti, maraṇamattampi dukkhaṁ.
analyzed: te tattha maraṇam pi nigacchanti maraṇa mattam pi dukkha
translated: and there they meet with death and deadly suffering.

translated: This is the danger in sensual pleasures, the mass of suffering visible here and now, which has sensual desire for its source, sensual desire for its origin, which is born from sensual desire, caused by sensual desire.

translated: Then the king’s men seize them and do with them as criminals.

original: Ayampi, mahānāma, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
analyzed: ayam pi mahānāma kāmānam ādīnavaḥ sandiṭṭhikaḥ dukkha kkhandhaḥ kāma hetu kāma nidānam kāma adhikaraṇam kāmānam eva hetu
translated: This is a danger in sensual pleasures visible here and now, a mass of suffering, mental and physical, born of sensual desire.

original: Puna caparaṁ, mahānāma, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu kāyena duccaritaṁ caranti, vācāya duccaritaṁ caranti, manasā duccaritaṁ caranti.
analyzed: punar capara mahā nāma kāma hetu kāma nidānam kāma adhikaraṇam kāmānam eva hetu kāyena duccaritam caranti vācāya duccaritam caranti manasā duccaritam caranti
translated: “Again, because of sensual pleasures, because of sensual desires, because of sensual thoughts, people do evil bodily actions, do evil verbal actions, and do evil mental actions.

original: Te kāyena duccaritaṁ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṁ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṁ caritvā, kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā, apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjanti.
analyzed: te kāyena duccaritam caritvā vācāya duccaritam caritvā manasā duccaritam caritvā kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapajjanti
translated: Having done evil bodily, verbal, and mental actions, with the breakup of the body, after death, they are reborn in a state of misery, in a bad destination, in the nether world, in hell.

original: Ayampi, mahānāma, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo samparāyiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
analyzed: ayam pi mahānāma kāmānam ādīnavaḥ samparāyikaḥ dukkha kkhandhaḥ kāma hetu kāma nidānam kāma adhikaraṇam kāmānam eva hetu
translated: This is a danger in sensual pleasures, a mass of suffering in the future, born of sensual desire.

original: Ekamidāhaṁ, mahānāma, samayaṁ rājagahe viharāmi gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
analyzed: ekam id āha mahā nāma samayam rājagahe viharāmi gijjhakūṭe pabbate
translated: “On one occasion, Mahanama, I was dwelling at Rajagaha at the Vultures’ Peak.

original: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā nigaṇṭhā isigilipasse kāḷasilāyaṁ ubbhaṭṭhakā honti āsanapaṭikkhittā, opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena sambahulāḥ nigaṇṭhāḥ isigili passe kāḷasilāyam ubbhaṭṭhakāḥ honti āsana paṭikkhittāḥ opakkamikāḥ dukkhāḥ tibbāḥ kharāḥ kaṭukāḥ vedanāḥ vedayanti
translated: At that time a number of Niganthas were standing on the Black Rock at the Isigili cliff, having undertaken to stand, rejecting seats, undergoing the pain, the extreme pain, the anguish of the bare wood.

original: Atha khvāhaṁ, mahānāma, sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena isigilipasse kāḷasilā yena te nigaṇṭhā tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā te nigaṇṭhe etadavocaṁ:
analyzed: atha khvā āha mahānāma sāyanha samayam paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitaḥ yena isigili passe kāḷasilā yena te nigaṇṭhā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā te nigaṇṭhe etat avoca
translated: Then, in the late afternoon, I came out from seclusion and went to the Black Rock at the Isigili cliff, and I said to the Niganthas:

original: ‘kiṁ nu tumhe, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, ubbhaṭṭhakā āsanapaṭikkhittā, opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayathā’ti?
analyzed: kim nu tumhe āvuso nigaṇṭhāḥ ubbhaṭṭhakāḥ āsana paṭikkhittāḥ opakkamikāḥ dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukāḥ vedanāḥ vedayatha ati
translated: ‘Friends, Niganthas, why are you standing on the Black Rock at the Isigili cliff, having undertaken to stand, rejecting seats, undergoing the pain, the extreme pain, the anguish of the bare wood?’

original: Evaṁ vutte, mahānāma, te nigaṇṭhā maṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: evam vutte mahānāma te nigaṇṭhāḥ mam etat avocuḥ
translated: When this was said, the Niganthas replied:

original: ‘nigaṇṭho, āvuso, nāṭaputto sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paṭijānāti:
analyzed: nigaṇṭhaḥ āvuso nāṭa putto sabbaññū sabba dassāvī aparisesam ñāṇa dassanam paṭijānāti
translated: ‘Friend, the Nigantha Nataputta claims to be all-knowing, all-seeing, to have all-embracing knowledge and vision,

original: “carato ca me tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṁ samitaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paccupaṭṭhitan”ti.
analyzed: carataḥ ca me tiṭṭhataḥ ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satatam samitam ñāṇa dassanam paccupaṭṭhitanti
translated: to be powerful and mighty, and to teach the truth, to be one who has realised the right insight into the higher knowledge of the destruction of suffering.

original: So evamāha:
analyzed: sā u evam āha
translated: He says:

original: “atthi kho vo, nigaṇṭhā, pubbe pāpakammaṁ kataṁ, taṁ imāya kaṭukāya dukkarakārikāya nijjīretha;
analyzed: atthi kho vaḥ nigaṇṭhāḥ pubbe pāpa kammam kata tat imāya kaṭukāya dukkara kārikāya nijjīretha
translated: ‘You ascetics have done bad things in the past, and now you are destroying them with this painful practice.

original: yaṁ panettha etarahi kāyena saṁvutā vācāya saṁvutā manasā saṁvutā taṁ āyatiṁ pāpassa kammassa akaraṇaṁ;🔽iti purāṇānaṁ kammānaṁ tapasā byantibhāvā, navānaṁ kammānaṁ akaraṇā, āyatiṁ anavassavo;
analyzed: yam pana itthā etarahi kāyena savutā vācāya savutā manasā savutā tam āyatim pāpassa kammassa  iti purāṇānam kammānam tapasā byantibhāvāḥ navānam kammānam akaraṇāḥ āyatim anavassavaḥ
translated: But you are now restrained in body, speech, and mind, and you will not do bad things in the future.🔽So through the destruction of old actions by painful deeds, and the non-doing of new actions, there will be no continuation of future suffering.

original: āyatiṁ anavassavā kammakkhayo, kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo, dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo, vedanākkhayā sabbaṁ dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: āyatim anavassavā kamma kkhayaḥ kamma kkhayā dukkha kkhayaḥ dukkha kkhayā vedanā kkhayaḥ vedanā kkhayā sabbam dukkham nijjiṇṇam bhavissati iti
translated: And through the ending of future suffering, all suffering will be exhausted.’

original: Tañca panamhākaṁ ruccati ceva khamati ca, tena camha attamanā’ti.
analyzed: tat ca panamhākam ruccati ca iva khamati ca tena camha
translated: We agree with this, and so we are satisfied.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, ahaṁ, mahānāma, te nigaṇṭhe etadavocaṁ:
analyzed: evam vutte aha mahānāma te nigaṇṭhe etat avoca
translated: When they had said this, I replied,

original: ‘kiṁ pana tumhe, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, jānātha—
analyzed: kim pana tumhe āvuso nigaṇṭhāḥ jānātha
translated: ‘But, friends, do you know

original: ahuvamheva mayaṁ pubbe na nāhuvamhā’ti?
analyzed: ahuvamha iva mayam pubbe na na ahuvamha ati
translated: that you existed in the past, and that it is not the case that you did not exist?’

original: ‘No hidaṁ, āvuso’.
analyzed: na u hide āvuso
translated: ‘No, friend.’

original: ‘Kiṁ pana tumhe, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, jānātha—
analyzed: kim pana tumhe āvuso nigaṇṭhāḥ jānātha
translated: ‘But, friends, do you know

original: akaramheva mayaṁ pubbe pāpakammaṁ na nākaramhā’ti?
analyzed: akaramha iva mayam pubbe pāpa kammam na na akaramha ati
translated: ‘We did bad things in the past, we didn’t do good things’?”

original: ‘No hidaṁ, āvuso’.🔽‘Kiṁ pana tumhe, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, jānātha—
analyzed: na u hide āvuso  kim pana tumhe āvuso nigaṇṭhāḥ jānātha
translated: “No, friend.”

original: evarūpaṁ vā evarūpaṁ vā pāpakammaṁ akaramhā’ti?
analyzed: evarūpam vā evarūpam vā pāpa kammam akaramha iti
translated: “But do you know what kind of bad things you did?”

original: ‘No hidaṁ, āvuso’.🔽‘Kiṁ pana tumhe, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, jānātha—
analyzed: na u hide āvuso  kim pana tumhe āvuso nigaṇṭhāḥ jānātha
translated: “No, friend.”

original: ettakaṁ vā dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ, ettakaṁ vā dukkhaṁ nijjīretabbaṁ, ettakamhi vā dukkhe nijjiṇṇe sabbaṁ dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ bhavissatī’ti?
analyzed: ettakam vā dukkham nijjiṇṇaḥ ettakam vā dukkham nijjīretabbaḥ ettakamhi vā dukkhe nijjiṇṇe sabbam dukkham nijjiṇṇam bhavissati iti
translated: “But do you know how much suffering you’ve ended, how much suffering you have left to end, and when all your suffering will end?”

original: ‘No hidaṁ, āvuso’.🔽‘Kiṁ pana tumhe, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, jānātha—
analyzed: na u hide āvuso  kim pana tumhe āvuso nigaṇṭhāḥ jānātha
translated: “No, friend.”

original: diṭṭheva dhamme akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānaṁ, kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ upasampadan’ti?
analyzed: diṭṭhe iva dhamme akusalānam dhammānam pahāna kusalānam dhammānam upasampadanti
translated: “But do you know that by developing the path in this very life you can end the unskillful and perfect the skillful?”

original: ‘No hidaṁ, āvuso’.🔽‘Iti kira tumhe, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, na jānātha—🔽ahuvamheva mayaṁ pubbe na nāhuvamhāti, na jānātha—
analyzed: na u hide āvuso  iti kira tumhe āvusaḥ nigaṇṭhāḥ na jānātha  ahuvamha iva mayam pubbe na na ahuvamha ati na jānātha
translated: “No, friend.”🔽“So it seems you don’t know whether you existed in the past,🔽whether you didn’t exist in the past,

original: akaramheva mayaṁ pubbe pāpakammaṁ na nākaramhāti, na jānātha—
analyzed: akaramha iva mayam pubbe pāpa kammam na na akaramha ati na jānātha
translated: whether you did bad things in the past,

original: evarūpaṁ vā evarūpaṁ vā pāpakammaṁ akaramhāti, na jānātha—
analyzed: evarūpam vā evarūpam vā pāpa kammam akaramha iti na jānātha
translated: ‘We don’t know if we’ve done such and such a bad action or not,

original: ettakaṁ vā dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ, ettakaṁ vā dukkhaṁ nijjīretabbaṁ, ettakamhi vā dukkhe nijjiṇṇe sabbaṁ dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ bhavissatīti.
analyzed: ettakam vā dukkham nijjiṇṇaḥ ettakam vā dukkham nijjīretabbaḥ ettakamhi vā dukkhe nijjiṇṇe sabbam dukkham nijjiṇṇam bhavissati iti
translated: how much suffering we’ve ended or how much is left to end, or how much suffering will be left to end when this much has been ended.’

original: Na jānātha—
analyzed: na jānātha
translated: You don’t know

original: diṭṭheva dhamme akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ pahānaṁ, kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ upasampadaṁ.
analyzed: diṭṭhe iva dhamme akusalānam dhammānam pahāna kusalānam dhammānam upasampada
translated: how to give up unskillful qualities and develop skillful qualities right in the present life.

original: Evaṁ sante, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, ye loke luddā lohitapāṇino kurūrakammantā manussesu paccājātā te nigaṇṭhesu pabbajantī’ti?
analyzed: evam sante āvuso nigaṇṭhāḥ ye loke luddāḥ lohita pāṇinaḥ kurūra kammantāḥ manussesu paccājātā te nigaṇṭhesu pabbajanti iti
translated: So, friends, those who are butchers, hunters, thieves, prison guards, executioners, or those who follow any other bloody occupation, they go forth in the Jains’ order.’

original: ‘Na kho, āvuso gotama, sukhena sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ, dukkhena kho sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ;
analyzed: na kho āvuso gotama sukhena sukham adhigantabba dukkhena kho sukham adhigantabba
translated: ‘Friend Gotama, happiness is not to be attained through happiness, but through suffering.

original: sukhena cāvuso gotama, sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ abhavissa, rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro sukhaṁ adhigaccheyya, rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro sukhavihāritaro āyasmatā gotamenā’ti.
analyzed: sukhena ca āvuso gotama sukham adhigantabbam abhavissa rājā māgadhaḥ seniyaḥ bimbisāraḥ sukham adhigaccheyya rājā māgadhaḥ seniyaḥ bimbisāraḥ sukha vihāritaraḥ āyasmatā gotamena ati
translated: If happiness were to be attained through happiness, then King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha would attain it, for he is happy and prosperous. He would be even more prosperous than he already is.’

original: ‘Addhāyasmantehi nigaṇṭhehi sahasā appaṭisaṅkhā vācā bhāsitā:
analyzed: addhā ayasmantehi nigaṇṭhehi sahasā appaṭisaṅkhā vācā bhāsitā
translated: ‘Surely, it was thoughtlessly that the Nigaṇṭhas spoke thus.

original: “na kho, āvuso gotama, sukhena sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ, dukkhena kho sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ;
analyzed: na kho āvuso gotama sukhena sukham adhigantabba dukkhena kho sukham adhigantabba
translated: ‘“It is not by pleasure that pleasure is to be obtained, but by pain that pleasure is to be obtained.

original: sukhena cāvuso gotama, sukhaṁ adhigantabbaṁ abhavissa, rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro sukhaṁ adhigaccheyya, rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro sukhavihāritaro āyasmatā gotamenā”ti.
analyzed: sukhena ca āvuso gotama sukham adhigantabbam abhavissa rājā māgadhaḥ seniyaḥ bimbisāraḥ sukham adhigaccheyya rājā māgadhaḥ seniyaḥ bimbisāraḥ sukha vihāritaraḥ āyasmatā gotamena ati
translated: If pleasure were to be obtained by pleasure, King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha would obtain pleasure, and he would be more pleasured than the venerable Gotama.”

original: Api ca ahameva tattha paṭipucchitabbo:

translated: But I should be asked:
